summary: James W. McCord, Jr. was a CIA employee. His personnel file details his personal information, education, and career assignments from 1948 to 1964. In 1965, he was reassigned within the Office of Security. In 1966, he was recommended for an Honor and Merit Award for his work improving the Agency's Audio-countermeasures Program, specifically in the development of a new fluoroscopic scanning technique for detecting clandestine microphones. The documents suggest a career focused on security and technical aspects within the CIA.
significance: Based on the provided documents, James W. McCord, Jr.'s significance in the JFK assassination context is not apparent. The documents focus on his CIA career and assignments related to security and audio-countermeasures.
